displayed_text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So that, that is also in the back of my mind. And, because, because then I feel like we might have actually harmed you by missing the opportunity to give, you know, an FDA-approved therapy. Of course, that would be through K___ because that would be standard therapy. Um, so that’s what the other part of my thinking. Patient: Okay. And, and from my perspective, I didn’t believe that this was going to be easy from the, from the beginning. I remember when I came, I came to J___ H___ for a reason. I came here for a consultation because I wasn’t comfortable, uh, with the options that I believe K___ was offering. I came initially for that reason. It’s strange that it was my dentist, so we talk about a lot. It’s strange how you get into certain things, uh, by having relationships with people who have gone through it. My dentist had, uh, numerous family members, had dealt with cancer, and he had recommended, he said, you know what, D___, this is what you need to do. You need to go to one of the teaching hospitals either here in DC you can go to J___ H___, in B___, and from my perspective, there are enough individuals that have come to J___ H___, that are close friends of mine. Doctor: Okay. Patient: That said, they shared with me that, uh, if you have a choice, go to J___ H___. So when I came up, my thing was the consultation. We had the consultation. I left, and, uh, and I didn’t say anything. But there was a follow-up that was set for J___ H___. And we sat down, and we talked about this. So we have all these options here. We did the genetic testing. And I said, okay, this is an option just like anything else. If it does not work, it’s not like it’s the only option that we have. Doctor: Correct. Patient: If it does not work. But, at the same time, I think you have to give the, uh, the drug the opportunity – to work. Doctor: Right. Patient: And that’s why initially when we started, and, uh, and L___, she said, well, Mr. S___, you have the clinical trial. And I believe we’ve, we’ve had, we took the clinical trial. I knew that the doses that I was going to have was, was in a low dosage, and I know it’s going to have some effect there. So my thing is, D___, deal with it as long as you can. So I did. We lowered it down. I have felt changes. I used to have pain, uh, running down this area. I mean serious pain. My back, wherever I used to have pain here, and, uh, I don’t have it anymore. Now, yes, she does rub me down every night. I take two hot, uh, uh, baths each day. Sometimes in the morning, sometimes at night. Uh, I take those hot baths because when I stiffen up or, and, uh, I kind of said, okay, I need to get in the tub. I put some Epsom salt sitting in, and I sit in the tub about fifteen minutes, and then I get back out. And I said, okay, I can deal with another day. So, again, from my perspective, is that I wanted to see the drug do what it needs to do. I don’t know what the window is. I’m not a medical professional, whatever, so I don’t know that. But I do know that I have seen, uh, uh, changes taking place. I do know that even now I could go and walk around this block. Uh, I shouldn’t, but I probably could. So, uh, the sleeping part, the OxyContin sometimes works, uh, when I take it and I go to sleep. But during the daytime while you’re at work, I normally, I can’t do what I used to do, but I can get along pretty good. We’re talking about at night. We’re talking about at night. And I’m trying to get comfortable in the bed. I wish I could sleep on my stomach but I haven’t figured out a way of, uh, sleeping back on my stomach like I used to. Uh, I just don’t feel comfortable when I sleep on my stomach. So, I’m not, uh, disagreeing with what you said your observations are, uh, but, I’m trying to work with the, with the prescription that we’re taking already. And I didn’t think it was going to be easy. If it was going to be easy, uh, this drug probably would have been FDA approved a long time ago, if it was going to be easy. You know? It may not work. But, again, you never know. We were off of it for, uh, I think three weeks. Family Member: Three weeks. Patient: Three weeks. And then I got a call from two doctors. I don’t even remember where their office is. And they said that, uh, my cancer had stabilized. Doctor: Um hum.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Um and then but so it’s nothing more than the usual. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then we have a point six percent of a seizure. So less than one percent of folks who normally have heavy alcohol intake. Patient: I don’t drink. Doctor: Right, so we give the stuff a lot in this clinic. Patient: Let me ask you this here. Doctor: Mm, hmm. Patient: What is the effects of a seizure? Doctor: Well a seizure is exactly what you see on TV you know when your brain is too hyperactive and you’re kind of going like this and you can’t control it. Patient: Okay so what do we do? And the reason why… Doctor: If that happens she’s calling nine one one, but it’s a percent chance less than that. Okay. Patient: Okay then let me ask you this here doc. Let me ask you this here. If I had a seizure

Family Member 1: And so like, now when he starts chemo or whatever and if he gets nauseous, I call M____? Doctor: Exactly. Yep. And you know, we'll make sure you have your prescription or whatever. Well, hopefully we'll have to give it to you so that, you know, when people run into trouble, it's always at 2 AM in the morning, right? Family Member 1: Right? Doctor: When you're like, “Uh oh, nowhere to go and no one to call.” So, first of all, you'll have that in your medicine cabinet. We'll make sure you have your nausea medication, because that's usually the thing that runs into trouble. You know, if you have diarrhea or constipation, that's over the counter that you can get, go to any 24 hour pharmacy for that. Family Member 1: Okay, yeah. Doctor: But things that are nausea medicines require prescriptions. Family Member 1: Do you do Zofran? Doctor: We do Zofran and we do Compazine. And then depending on the level of how much nausea you know. Family Member 1: Zofran works for me. I got pneumonia. Doctor: Well, you're right. And I think the important part here is that this is not a big nausea, type of chemo. There are some where you're like, “Okay, brace yourself, it's going to happen.” This is pretty mild. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It's actually called a mild emetogenic. So it just means it’s not gonna make you puke, but everybody's different.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: that’s it. Just one time. Patient: Right. Doctor: Um and it’s proven to help improve for you to live longer. Patient: Right. Doctor: For folks just like you. Patient: Right. Doctor: Okay. It comes with side effects because it’s never nothing without nothing. Patient: What is the side effects? Doctor: Number one, two and three is tiredness. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And tiredness isn’t that your brain isn’t functioning, functioning great. Patient: Just physically tired?

Patient: Um hum. Doctor: And then a third group that doesn’t respond at all. Uh, so that would be the easiest thing. That’s a, you know, that’s the prescription. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That, that’s choice one. Choice two would be to give you chemotherapy at this point. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, I think, for me, what I would prefer is to try another hormone pill before we do chemotherapy. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Particularly because you’re not really symptomatic right now, I don’t think, and, you know, the, the benefits of both, uh, are about the same. Uh, so, and the side effects of chemotherapy are just, you know-? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: More to deal with. So, so if we were going to choose, uh, I would probably choose one of the hormone pills as the next thing to do. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, the clinical trials that we have, uh, at this point, uh, whether you’re ready to do another clinical trial after having just been on one. (Laughter) Doctor: Uh, the one upside of clinical trials is, you might of noticed, is you get a research nurse who kind of is like your concierge who runs everything for you.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.1 time: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::1 time

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.agree: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::agree

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.neutral: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::neutral

A doctor would never mislead you about a.neutral: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::neutral

All in all, you trust doctors completely.disagree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::disagree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.agree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups:::agree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.agree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers:::agree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Employed: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Employed

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Asian: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Asian

displayed_text: Patient: I know. I know it. Doctor: It’s fixing the fungal infection then just to wait until it comes right back. Patient: I agree. Doctor: So… Patient: Well. Doctor: Do you want to see a urologist here today? Family Member: That’s what I told him – yeah. Doctor: Let me ask. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Because we have Dr. Lucas here and … Family Member: Okay. Patient: The last urologist I went to back home I walked out because I sat there for two hours and I’m out of here. Family Member: Every time you go there I mean you can’t get in to see him. I mean you’re there for hours.

Family Member: Um hum. Patient: Right. Doctor: But, and it’s also a drug that if you take it long-term, you can get side effects from it, in terms of immune system. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: People tend to, you know, it tends to pop your appetite up, so you feel like you want to eat more. Patient: Give me the glasses. Doctor: It can also affect your skin. Some people, their skin gets very thin, and they bruise easily, particularly at the higher doses. So we, we could try the other one. I, I mean- Family Member: But you feel that would be less tiresome-? Doctor: Well, I just tell you my global experience with both drugs. Doctor: Has been it seems like both of them has a side effect, fatigue. Patient: Okay. Doctor: But my experience with using both drugs now, it seems like it’s a little bit more with the Xtandi. Uh, and the other question is, you know, we do have a couple of trials of Xtandi, uh, that, uh, I don’t know if you’re interested in going on another trial at this point. (Sound Door opens)

Family Member: Okay. Doctor: And I know that we want to be as aggressive as possible with you. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: Because sometimes when your disease decides to do something, we need to quiet it down quick. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: You had a shot in June. So your next one isn’t, you know, until September. Family Member: Right. Right. Doctor: But we haven’t had a scan since April of last year. So we might as well get one this year. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: See how things are. You know? See how the lymph nodes and bone stuff is doing just to make sure we don’t have to do anything exciting. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: You okay with that? So that’s the CAT scan again, there’s the chest, the bone in the pelvis, and then the bone scan, which is basically stuff like that. Just to make sure. Patient: Hum. Hum.

Healthcare Professional: Yes, okay. Doctor: So get in touch with ___ and/or myself. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And let me know that you’re coming actually the week after that. Like as soon as you feel you kinda know and then if we do go down the route of radiation therapy I can refer you to the radiation oncologist here to do that treatment. Patient: Okay, and now what would your role continue to be when I move to another physician? Doctor: Yes, I don’t deliver radiation therapy since I’m a medical oncologist. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: So in the short term you go down that route and do the other therapy and they monitor you on that, and then once that part of it’s completed you’d come back to – Patient: Um hum. Come back to you, okay. You stay in the loop somewhere. Doctor: My hands Dr.__ is also going to be in the loop because he is the one who referred you. Patient: Yes, yes, I’ll have to; I’ll make an appointment with him. I saw him about maybe about six weeks ago and he had mentioned that they were starting up some trials in GW. I’m more comfortable where I am now, to be very honest with you. Doctor: Uh hum.

Patient: Good. You remember my daughter, E_______? Doctor: Yes, of course! Family Member: Hi. Doctor: She was your-- Family Member: Nice to see you! Doctor: Lucky charm. Patient: You're right. Doctor: Okay, we have a medical student. I think they told you that he will be in. Did she tell you that? Patient: Yeah. That's right, yeah. That's right. Doctor: Um, okay, that um... Patient: That's fine. Patient: Good. The drops have been helping. Doctor: The redness is all gone. How about the tearing? Even that is better?

Patient: No. I don’t have any. Doctor: Still any numbness around your mouth or-? Patient: A little bit when, you know, coughing. Doctor: So. So how often are you taking the morphine? Patient: About two at night. Doctor: A little, nothing during the day? Patient: No. Doctor: Okay. How’s your bowels been? Patient: Okay. Doctor: So slow? That’s what you told me last time. Patient: Yeah, but, you know. Doctor: Still moving daily?

Patient: Right. Doctor: If you have only one bathroom you'll just be very diligent you'll get some gloves you wipe down after you use the bathroom with because chemo- Family Member: With what? Doctor: Oh with Lysol Clorox anything over the counter you got the wipes. They all work. Family Member 1: Wipes work? Flush twice? Doctor: Yep flush twice and then with the wipes put them in the garbage, but just keep it separate. Patient: Right. Doctor: You know you have a toddler you don't want to- Family Member 1: Well, can he be around? Doctor: - and they just get into it. Family Member 1: Can he still baby sit for A___ when he’s on this medicine? Because we do split shifts. Doctor: So yeah, so that that's a little bit of the hard part. Not so much for you to her, but for her to you. Because if they're their little ones are germy they're just one giant viral bacterial fest, because that's what they they do and they pick up everything. You would be a bit compromised from that. Family Member 1: Could he wear a mask if he wanted?

Patient: No. Um, none at this time. Doctor: Okay. So, what we’ll do is we’ll um we’ll be able to answer some questions over the phone when we call you as well in about a week. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Talk to you about the clinical trials. If you read through this and you say thanks but no thanks, that’s perfectly fine. I’m still going to be your doc and I’m still going to be your oncologist. Um and you have every right you know to turn this down if it’s not right for you. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: But this a reasonable option that um if I was the patient, I would also consider. So I will leave that with you, put that underneath this one. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: And then uh we will get back in touch with you either later this week- Patient: Mhm. Doctor: Or early next week. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: And uh-

Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Okay, and I was like just and then she was on the phone, I was like did she mean now or did she mean before? Family Member: No, because he was in pain; he was in pain. Doctor: Where is your worst pain do you think? Patient: Right here. Doctor: Still. Well, you’ve got some new spots on the bone scan. That’s one of them and upper spine is the other, you know kind of like of like by the neck area. So I don’t think this Xtandi is holding you as much as we’d like. Family Member: But it is holding him, right? Doctor: Some parts of it but I think we have to think about adding something else to the mix here or stopping it. And I just want to double-check. You’re still taking Xtandi? Okay, and are you alternating like number of pills per day or are you just - Patient: Four a day. Doctor: Okay, so you know you don’t have much room to go from that because that’s the max dose. But when you break through from the bone scan it tells me it’s really not working. The stuff that’s being not - you know it’s not in your liver or anything else. Like it’s just still in the bone and you’ve got pain actually suggests we could try a different treatment called Xofigo. And I mentioned this like a while back. This is that radium stuff that Marie Curie discovered many years ago. I don’t know if you guys remember that from elementary school. But it basically kills, you know, cancer in the bones. Well in her case she died because she was carrying too much of it in her pocket. But in patients, it’s now in legit treatment for men with prostate cancer that has gone to bone. Family Member: Does that look - something you inject, like a pill or capsule or something? Doctor: No, it’s actually, they put an I.V. in you and it comes in a – it’s a liquid. It’s like liquid radiation, and they draw it up and then they just inject it in you. It’s like you know, it’s like in, in over a minute, and it’s once a month for six months. The person that is the expert is the radiation oncology doctor, and that person knows how to regulate obviously radiation. This is a form of radiation. Family Member: Is that what they did to him before when he went down there? They -

Patient: Doc, Doc, Doc, that’s another thing. Doctor: What? Patient: I ain’t going to the bathroom regularly and started taking my stool softeners and then I’m mixing up the what-ya-call-it too. Doctor: Yep, that’s what you gotta do. You want me to put this here? I just gave him the side effect sheet. Patient: I need. Family Member: I was gonna look them up anyway. Patient: Let me say this here, Doc. Let me say this here. Everything that you tell me and you do – Doctor: Mm,hmm. Patient: she goes and she looks up everything Doctor: Perfect. Yes. Patient: You know I’m just surrounded with just good people taking good care. Doctor: People who care. Here’s what I said about the bike trip. It’s up to him really to be smart about it. You know I know he loves it and this is something he just has to work out by himself and also with you guys. There’s no real medical reason technically and it’s gonna take us a week or two to get that medicine, so there’s time. He says he’s not gonna stay down in F____.
